> **
>
>
> Hi everybody,
>
> I just=
 would like to recommend you the article "Evolution of declarative
> memory=
" by Manns and Eichenbaum.
>
> http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16881079
=
>
> It is basically a review of the hippocampus which emphasizes an
> evolu=
tionary perspective to understand its functional role. Here is a quote:
>
>=
 "[...] we advance the argument that an evolutionary approach is the key to=

> understanding the fundamental functional role of the mammalian hippocamp=
us.
> In each mammalian species, a remarkably conserved hippocampus is wrap=
ped in
> a unique neocortex. The divergent neocortex cloaks the conserved
>=
 hippocampal function by requiring a species-specific translation of
> inco=
ming sensory information before it reaches the hippocampus and of
> retriev=
ed associations before they can be reflected in behavior. Thus,
> results f=
rom experimental animals may appear incompatible with results from
> humans=
 unless the differences in neocortical organization are taken into
> accoun=
t. According to this view, the kind of information processed by
> cortical =
areas may differ among species, but the intrinsic computations of
> the hip=
pocampal system are conserved. Thus, a computational account of
> hippocamp=
al function can best reveal and characterize hippocampal
> functional circu=
itry in a way that applies equally well across species."
>
> I found this a=
rticle very inspiring as it illustrates that the hippocampus
> (which is an=
atomically very similar across species) is maybe a good
> starting point to=
 study the relation between the anatomy ( =3D spatial
> relations between n=
eurons + their projection directions) of a network an
> its functional role=
 in learning.
>
> Best,
> Martin
>
>  
>

r><blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:=
1px #ccc solid;padding-left:1ex">




<u></u>










<div style>
<span>=
=A0</span>


<div>
  <div>


    <div>
      
      
      <p>Hi everybody,=
<br>
<br>
I just would like to recommend you the article "Evolution of=
 declarative memory" by Manns and Eichenbaum. <br>
<br>
<a href=3D"htt=
p://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16881079" target=3D"_blank">http://www.ncbi=
.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16881079</a><br>
<br>
It is basically a review of the h=
ippocampus which emphasizes an evolutionary perspective to understand its f=
unctional role. Here is a quote:<br>
<br>
"[...] we advance the argume=
nt that an evolutionary approach is the key to understanding the fundamenta=
l functional role of the mammalian hippocampus. In each mammalian species, =
a remarkably conserved hippocampus is wrapped in a unique neocortex. The di=
vergent neocortex cloaks the conserved hippocampal function by requiring a =
species-specific translation of incoming sensory information before it reac=
hes the hippocampus and of retrieved associations before they can be reflec=
ted in behavior. Thus, results from experimental animals may appear incompa=
tible with results from humans unless the differences in neocortical organi=
zation are taken into account. According to this view, the kind of informat=
ion processed by cortical areas may differ among species, but the intrinsic=
 computations of the hippocampal system are conserved. Thus, a computationa=
l account of hippocampal function can best reveal and characterize hippocam=
pal functional circuitry in a way that applies equally well across species.=
"<br>


<br>
I found this article very inspiring as it illustrates tha=
t the hippocampus (which is anatomically very similar across species) is ma=
ybe a good starting point to study the relation between the anatomy ( =3D s=
patial relations between neurons + their projection directions) of a networ=
k an its functional role in learning. <br>


<br>
Best,<br>
Martin<br>
<br>=

</p>

    </div>
